business.headline: Retail inflation at 2.75% in January as India shifts to new CPI base year 2024The data, released by the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation, reflects a major statistical overhaul aimed at making India's inflation measure more representative of current consumption patterns.

A 90-year-old man was sold a 100-year policy. Why blaming the bank is not enoughHandcrafted ByOur Editors A 90-year-old man was sold an insurance policy maturing in 2124. The case sounds bizarre. But instances of mis-selling like this are painfully common across the country. The bank resolved the matter after a viral social media post. The harder question is why blaming the bank alone is not enough.

Sensex sinks over 500 points, Nifty tumbles as AI panic sinks IT stocksThe benchmark BSE Sensex fell 559 points to close at 85,674.92, while the Nifty 50 slipped below the psychologically important 25,900 mark.

Aviation body writes to government as it bids to tighten cabin crew fatigue ruleThe Federation of Indian Airlines (FIA) has asked the government to dilute parts of the draft rules. The industry body represents IndiGo and Air India, and has raised concerns that the changes may create operational and cost pressures.

IT stocks crack under global AI pressure. Is this a buying chance?The Nifty IT index fell 4.67% by 12 PM, hitting a four-month low. The selloff wiped out nearly Rs 1.3 lakh crore in combined market value in a single session. The IT pack on the Sensex was also down nearly 5%.

Inflation data reset: Why your groceries will matter less than your rentOnion or tomato prices will no longer dominate inflation headlines. With rent and services gaining weight, the new data reset could quietly shape your EMIs, savings returns and everyday financial decisions. Read on to understand what has changed and why it matters for your wallet.

Gold, silver cool off after sharp correction. Is it a good chance to buy?Gold and silver have corrected sharply after record highs. Is this the right time to buy or a warning sign? Here is a simple breakdown of what it means for you.

India-US trade deal to benefit local industries: New Delhi envoy to WashingtonIndian ambassador to the United States, Vinay Kwatra, in an exclusive interview with India Today, said that the newly-reached trade deal between India and the US will benefit the two nations.

Infosys, TCS, Wipro tumble up to 5%: Why are IT stocks falling today?From US jobs data to mounting AI disruption fears, here is a clear breakdown of what triggered today's IT sell-off and what investors should watch next.
Sensex down 500 points: Why is stock market falling today?The S&P BSE Sensex was down by 515.63 points to 83,718.01, while the NSE Nifty50 lost 132.85 points to 25,821.00 as of 11:39 am.

Sensex, Nifty open lower as IT stocks tank over global selloff; Infosys down 4%The S&P BSE Sensex was down by 360.77 points to 83,872.87, while the NSE Nifty50 lost 99.70 points to 25,854.15 as of 9:21 am.

RBI finally takes note of mis-selling, banks to refund if complaint is provedOver the past few years, concerns have been raised about customers being pushed into buying insurance, mutual funds or other third-party products without fully understanding them.

Rolls-Royce CEO meets PM in Delhi, discusses plans to scale up India opsRolls-Royce CEO Tufan Erginbilgic met Prime Minister Narendra Modi in Delhi to discuss plans to substantially expand the British engineering giant's operations in India in line with the government's Viksit Bharat vision.

UBS to hire 3,000 roles in India as Credit Suisse takeover triggers Swiss job cutsUBS bought Credit Suisse in a state-engineered rescue in 2023, leaving it as Switzerland's sole major banking group. It has said around 3,000 Swiss jobs will be cut, most likely later this year.

Gold, silver or Bitcoin? Will crypto steal the spotlightGold and silver have long been seen as safe havens for investors, a reliable store of value in uncertain times. But with the rise of Bitcoin and other cryptocurrencies, the question on everyone's mind is: could cryptos steal the spotlight?

Pace and ease of doing business drive Tamil Nadu's edge, says TRB RajaaRajaa said that investors value policy continuity as much as fresh reforms, noting that Tamil Nadu has built trust by maintaining stable, industry-friendly rules across political regimes. He added that this continuity has strengthened global investor confidence in the state.

AI is disrupting more than just tech and IT stocks. What investors should knowThe panic around AI is now spreading across Wall Street, moving beyond tech to hit wealth management stocks as well. In this article, we break down what's happening and what retail investors should know.

From SBI, PNB to Suryoday Small Finance Bank: A look at latest FD rates across banksInterest rates vary widely depending on how long the money is locked in. In many cases, three-year and five-year deposits offer better returns than shorter tenures. At the same time, depositors should balance higher rates with factors such as bank safety, liquidity needs and their own financial goals.

Sensex, Nifty pause 3-day rally as IT stocks limit gains on D-StreetSensex, Nifty closed lower. Both indices had gained nearly 1.2% in the previous three sessions. The rally was driven by hopes around a possible U.S.-India trade deal.

Ease and speed of doing business put Tamil Nadu on top, says TRB RajaaRajaa said Tamil Nadu's unique strength lies in being India's talent capital, adding that the state produces around 150,000 engineers and benefits from a strong talent pool built through heavy investment in education.

entertainment.headline: Yash's Toxic expands reach, finalises North India distribution deal Yash's Toxic: A Fairy Tale for Grown-Ups is set for a multi-language release on March 19. Anil Thadani's AA Films secures distribution rights across North India and Nepal.

Why Fighter didn't match Pathaan box office numbers: Siddharth Anand explains Director Siddharth Anand discussed the box office performance of Fighter, starring Hrithik Roshan and Deepika Padukone. In a recent interview, he explained why he believes the film did not meet commercial expectations.

Anne Hathaway backs Bad Bunny's message of love, unity in Super Bowl show Anne Hathaway reacted to Bad Bunny's historic Super Bowl Halftime Show performance earlier this week. Calling it "amazing," she praised his message of love, unity, and protecting "neighbours."

No bail for Rajpal Yadav, court says he failed to honour commitment The Delhi High Court on Thursday pulled up Rajpal Yadav during his bail hearing, telling the actor that he failed to honour his commitment and then reopened the case. The court adjourned the hearing to Monday.

Riteish Deshmukh calls Genelia his safe space as they celebrate 24 years of love Riteish Deshmukh and Genelia D'Souza celebrated 24 years of togetherness with heartfelt messages for each other on social media.

Nikhil's Swayambhu teaser blends mythology and history, draws reactions 2026 is shaping up as a year of ambitious projects, with Nikhil Siddhartha joining the list with Swayambhu. The film's teaser is out now.

Bhumi Pednekar recalls SRK's praise for her debut film: There was a lot of love Bhumi Pednekar recalled an unforgettable meeting with Shah Rukh Khan at YRF Studios, where the superstar praised her performance in Dum Laga Ke Haisha.

Ratna Pathak Shah slams entourage culture: I don't want this infantilisation Ratna Pathak Shah has criticised the industry's entourage system, calling it a wasteful cycle that infantilises actors. She warned that this "self-feeding" system distances individuals from their instincts and creates a financial bubble that will eventually burst due to a lack of accountability.

Taapsee Pannu urges fans to support stories rooted in reality ahead of Assi Taapsee Pannu urged audiences to support rooted real stories and watch her upcoming film Assi in theatres instead of blaming the industry for lack of meaningful cinema.

Ratna Pathak praises Alia Bhatt's focus on Kapoor & Sons set: Was very impressed Ratna Pathak Shah praised Alia Bhatt for her attentiveness and discipline on the Kapoor & Sons set, recalling how the actor quietly observed others to improve her craft.

How Barun Sobti outgrew the heartthrob tag and turned to more real, layered roles Barun Sobti's acting career shows a shift from idealised romantic leads to deeply human roles. His changing choices reflect evolving audience preferences and modern masculinity.

The Kerala Story sequel shot amid tight security? Producer responds The Kerala Story 2 Goes Beyond was filmed with heightened security measures to protect the cast and crew. Producer Vipul Amrutlal Shah denies rumours of disruptions, aiming for a smooth release despite sensitive themes.

Radhika Sarathkumar recalls dark skin insecurity during scene with Kamal Haasan Radhika Sarathkumar recalled how insecurities about her complexion affected her confidence in her early film career, including during a scene with Kamal Haasan, while also reflecting on changing beauty standards in the industry.

Priyanka Chopra on her decision to pursue Hollywood career at 30: It was terrifying Priyanka Chopra opened up about the "terrifying" experience of restarting her career in Hollywood at thirty. She recalled facing stereotypes as she rejected novelty casting to pursue "borderless entertainment."

Blake Lively, Justin Baldoni fail to reach settlement, trial set for May 2026 Blake Lively and Justin Baldoni could not resolve their legal dispute during a court-ordered settlement conference in New York, with a trial now scheduled for 18 May. Newly unsealed documents and viral exchanges add to the high-profile case.

He-Man, Super Mario, Street Fighter: 90s nostalgia set to hit superhero space '90s Hollywood legends return with fresh fire — Mario soaring through the stars, fighters trading blows, He-Man claiming his destiny. Past efforts had their stumbles, but today's takes honour the magic that started it all, adding bold new chapters while capes keep flying strong.

Trump may sweeten trade deal for India further after Bangladesh concessionsA clause of zero tariffs on Bangladesh textile exports to the US in the trade deal left the Indian textile industry. However, Piyush Goyal has now given an important clarification. We explain the issue for you.

Close to China border, India turns highway into runway for Rafales, GlobemastersPM Narendra Modi on Saturday is set to land on a 4.2-km Emergency Landing Facility carved out of a National Highway in Dibrugarh district of Assam. It isn't far from the Line of Actual Control (LAC) with China. The landing will mark the operationalisation of the Northeast's first highway airstrip, where Rafales, Sukhois and heavy-lift aircraft like Globemasters are expected to take part in a mega airshow.

Too late now to say sorry: Norwegian athlete cheats, plays victim, ruins the momentA moment to win the heart of the 'gold medal of his life' has found Sturla Holm Laegrid deliver one of the most bizarre and controversial athlete interviews of all time. By putting his partner in a rough spot and stealing the thunder from his teammate, Laegrid's words were right but delivered at the wrong moment.

With Sanju Samson in and Jasprit Bumrah returning, can the hero find his rhythm before the Colombo clash with the main villain?

India to get 114 Rafale jets as government clears Rs 3.25 lakh crore deal: SourcesUnder the deal, nearly 80 per cent of the 114 Rafale jets are expected to be manufactured domestically, with indigenous content possibly reaching 60 per cent under the Make in India framework.

Microsoft AI boss says AI will replace most white-collar jobs in 12 monthsMicrosoft AI chief Mustafa Suleyman believes that AI could replace most white collar jobs including lawyers, accountants and more, within the next year. His comments come days after Anthropic's Claude Cowork shook the stocks of SaaS companies.

Elon Musk wants to launch spacecraft from Moon to hunt for aliensElon Musk outlines exciting plans for Moonbase Alpha featuring mass drivers to launch AI satellites into deep space. The ambitious vision includes self-sustaining lunar cities and searches for remnants of ancient alien civilisations.

Live: Voting ends with 48% turnout, ballot counting beginsBangladesh General Election Live Updates: Bangladesh General Election Live Updates: The voting process in Bangladesh's first general election after the fall of the Sheikh Hasina government has concluded. Ballot counting has started after reports of sporadic violence and accusations of cheating. Votes were also cast on the July Charter, which, if approved, will give the next government the authority to make big changes in the country's Constitution and democratic system. The key fight is between the alliances led by the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) and the Jamaat-e-Islami. We have been bringing you live updates on the voting, reactions, and analyses from our trusted sources and reporters on the ground. Follow indiatoday.in for the latest updates on the voting and results process.

Bengaluru man clings to speeding car's bonnet in shocking road rage videoA man was dragged on the bonnet of a moving car in broad daylight in Bengaluru due to a road rage incident. This raised serious concerns over road safety and aggressive driving in the city.

Kidnapped in Azerbaijan, torture live-streamed to family: Duo's US journey horrorWhat began as a dream of reaching the US turned into a nightmare for two youths from Gujarat, who were kidnapped, tortured, and threatened with organ trafficking in Azerbaijan. However, they were swiftly rescued by India authorities in 'Operation Mahisagar' after S Jaishankar was alerted by the Anand MP.

It is expected that ICC will also mediate the relationship between the boards during that game.

Lamborghini crash: Tycoon's son planted dummy driver to shift blame, say copsAfter being on the run for four days, the son of a Kanpur tobacco tycoon was arrested on Thursday after he rammed his Lamborghini into pedestrians. The police, in their application before the court, said Shivam Mishra fled the scene and attempted to shift blame to a 'dummy driver'.

A mountain on the Moon: Why Chandrayaan-4 could land on Mons MoutonIsro recently released a new scientific study based on high-resolution imagery from India's lunar orbiter that analysed four potential landing sites in the region.

When childhood goes online: Data leaks, addiction and digital predatorsChildren are going online younger than ever, often driven by visibility, performance or parental posting. We talk about three major digital harms -- data overexposure, compulsive online behaviour, and AI-enhanced grooming -- with expert insight from cybersecurity, psychology and parenting fields, showing why safety needs a new strategy for today's digital age.

X product head warns calls, messages and emails may become unusable in 90 daysNikita Bier, the product head of Elon Musk's social media platform X, believes that within 90 days, emails, messages and everything we use to communicate will become unusable due to automated spamming.

sports.headline: Drafted as Australia's T20 World Cup cover, Steve Smith scripts PSL history Steve Smith set a new record as PSL's most expensive player after being signed by the Sialkot Stallions for PKR 14 crore in the league's first ever auction. PSL 11 will feature two new franchises, Sialkot and Hyderabad, and a change from draft to auction format, as over 100 players secured contracts ahead of the season starting March 26.

Federer still the box office GOAT: Hall of Fame tickets sold out in 120 seconds Is Roger Federer the best-selling tennis player of all time? Tickets for his Hall of Fame induction ceremony sold out in just 2 minutes. This happened despite the organisation adding more tickets for the event.

After argument during SA vs AFG, Mohammad Nabi fined for code of conduct breach Mohammad Nabi was fined 15 percent of his match fee and given one demerit point after an argument with the umpires during Afghanistan's T20 World Cup 2026 Group D clash against South Africa in Ahmedabad. Nabi admitted his offence and accepted the sanction.

SL vs OMA: Sri Lanka set for Australia challenge after hammering Oman T20 World Cup: A clinical performance with the bat from Kusal Mendis and Pavan Rathnayake, followed by disciplined bowling helped Sri Lanka make it two in two with a thumping win over Oman in Pallekele on Thursday, February 12.

Defeated yet defiant: Harry Brook defends England's spin-playing abilities T20 World Cup 2026: Harry Brook defended England's ability to play spin in the sub-continent after their loss to West Indies in Mumbai on Wednesday, February 11. Brook also brushed aside concerns about Jofra Archer's form and the lessons they got from the first two games.

The Windies not only put decent runs on board but also bowled England out in a chase-friendly venue as Mumbai.

Smashed for 90 in 8, yet Archer finds support from England captain Brook T20 World Cup: England captain Harry Brook has backed Jofra Archer to bounce back after his expensive start to his T20 World Cup 2026 campaign. Archer has conceded more than 40 runs in the first two games of the tournament.

From JJ Smit to Jan Frylinck: 5 Namibia stars who can derail India's chargeT20 World Cup, IND vs NAM: JJ Smit, Ruben Trumpelmann and Jan Frylinck are among the Namibian cricketers who could pose a significant threat to India when the two teams meet in their group-stage clash on Thursday at the Arun Jaitley Stadium in New Delhi.

By putting his partner in a rough spot and stealing the thunder from his teammate, Laegrid's words were right but delivered at the wrong moment.

Visualiser. New-age T20 anchor. The many shades of India's No.3 Tilak VarmaT20 World Cup: In an Indian batting order dominated by flamboyant stroke-makers, Tilak Varma is prepared to rein himself in as a Virat Kohli-esque anchor at No.3 when the situation demands. But beyond the tactical role, he is a visualiser, a batter who prepares as much in his mind as he does in the nets.

Matchday Preview: Nepal look to bounce back after England heartbreakDay 5 of the T20 World Cup 2026 features a triple-header with Sri Lanka looking to continue their momentum against Oman. Following their heartbreaking loss to England, Nepal will aim to bounce back strongly against Italy. All eyes will be on defending champions India as they face off against Namibia in Delhi.

Rohit Sharma lays down roadmap for ODI WC 2027: Will do everything to win itFormer India captain Rohit Sharma has reconfirmed his ambition to win the 2027 ODI World Cup in South Africa. Rohit's form was in question in the recent New Zealand series, where he scored 61 runs from three innings.

Rajasthan's champions run pillar to post as crores in prize money remain unpaidThis report on 5ive Live, hosted by Sonal Mehrotra Kapoor, exposes how medal-winning athletes in Rajasthan are trapped in bureaucratic delays, waiting years for promised prize money. Asian Games paramedalist Rakesh owes Rs 8-10 lakh for state and national medals won between 2021 and 2025. National hammer throw record-holder Neeraj Kumar has waited over 4 years for Rs 50-70,000. Disc thrower Praveen Kumar Nehra hasn't received Rs 5 lakh since 2016-2017, with a 2019 guideline blocking pre-2019 payments. Cyclist Devendra Bishnui, despite winning 8 medals, has received nothing, while competitive cycles cost over Rs 5 lakh. Nearly 90 per cent of medal winners remain unpaid, forcing some champions into survival jobs like cab driving and food delivery. The Rajasthan Sports Council attributes delays to "ongoing processes" and new online systems, but athletes continue waiting while their careers and financial stability deteriorate.

Steve Smith an automatic choice for Australia in T20 World Cup? Nathan Ellis revealsT20 World Cup, AUS vs IRE: Speaking to the reporters after the win against Ireland on Wednesday, Nathan Ellis opened up on whether Steve Smith would be included in the team if Mitchell Marsh doesn't recover from his groin injury.

Men's T20 World Cup snub behind, Bangladesh launches another new T20 leagueOn Wednesday, the Bangladesh Cricket Board (BCB) launched the inaugural Women's Bangladesh Premier League, which is set to be held in April later this year. Recently, the BCB also introduced the Odommo T20 Cup for the men's team following their decision to boycott the T20 World Cup.

Afghanistan lost to South Africa in double super over fixture on Wednesday, February 11.

10 years on, West Indies channel 2016 magic to crush England at WankhedeT20 World Cup 2026: With two wins on the bounce and Darren Sammy at the helm, the West Indies channel their 2016 spirit to crush England at Wankhede once more, defending 196 with a clinical spin-led performance.

Nathan Ellis opens up on Mitchell Marsh's injury scareT20 World Cup, AUS vs IRE: Nathan Ellis addressed Mitchell Marsh's injury scare after the skipper missed Australia's opener with a groin issue, but insisted the squad remained calm and unfazed under stand-in captain Travis Head.

Neeraj Chopra's South Africa training extended, Sports Ministry approves fundsThe Sports Ministry's Mission Olympic Cell has approved an extension of Neeraj Chopra's training in South Africa till April, providing comprehensive financial support for his pre-season preparation.

Maharaj over Rabada or Jansen: Rickelton explains brave Super Over call vs AfghanistanT20 World Cup, SA vs AFG: Speaking to the reporters after the thrilling encounter, Ryan Rickelton opened up on why South Africa proffered Keshav Maharaj over Kagiso Rabada and Marco Jansen for the second Super Over against Afghanistan.

European Super League project comes to an end with Real Madrid's agreement with UEFAReal Madrid reached an agreement with UEFA on Wednesday, officially ending the controversial Super League project that attempted to break away from traditional European soccer in 2021.

Suryakumar bhai and I can perform the role of anchor if needed: Tilak VarmaHere's the full transcript of India batter Tilak Varma's press conference ahead of their February 12 match against Namibia in the T20 World Cup 2026. 

[Reporter:]
Tilak, what is the situation of Abhishek who was admitted to the hospital? Is he fine? Is he still in the hospital, or is he with the team at the hotel?

[Tilak Verma:]
When we reached Delhi, he went for some examinations at the hospital. I think he has been discharged today, and he's doing well. We still have one more day before the game, so hopefully we'll decide by tomorrow how he feels and then move forward accordingly.

[Reporter:]
When you play against less experienced teams, their field placements, bowling speeds, and shot selections can be different. Does that make it difficult for teams like India to adjust? What adjustments do you have to make?

[Tilak Verma:]
Especially with these newer teams, you can't take anyone lightly. You saw that in the last match. It wasn't that we took them lightly, but we didn't read the conditions properly. After that, Surya bhai came in and played a great innings, which helped the team a lot.
At the same time, we should always back our basics and play our best game. Whatever the field or situation, you have to read it ball by ball. T20 cricket is a very short format—anything can happen, and any team can beat anyone. So it's important to bring your A-game in every match.

[Reporter:]
Yesterday it was said that Jasprit Bumrah had started bowling again after 10 days. He was in the nets for quite a long time. What is the update on him? Will he be available for tomorrow's game?

[Tilak Verma:]
He is absolutely fine now. He's doing better. As I said, we still have one more day, so hopefully he'll be back in the team. If he continues to improve, the team management will take a call, and I think he could be back for the second game.

[Reporter:]
Tilak bhai, tomorrow there's a match, and after that, another big one in Colombo. There has been a lot of discussion around it. As a player, what were you thinking? Was there any discussion about whether you would play or not?

[Tilak Verma:]
No, sir. To be honest, we're actually excited to play now. We found out that the match is going to happen, and we were already preparing for it. We've been watching the opposition, studying their bowlers, and preparing as batsmen.
When we heard the match would be played, all the players and staff were excited. We're in match mode now, and the planning has started.

[Reporter:]
Can you talk about your comeback from injury, playing at number three, and your new role compared to what you were doing before?

[Tilak Verma:]
Yes, sir. I'm really happy to be back in the World Cup squad. I worked hard over the last two or three weeks and followed good routines. God has been kind, and I returned to the field quickly.
My aim is to help the team win the World Cup. I'm ready for whatever role the team wants from me. I've always said I'm ready to bat wherever the team needs me. I'm prepared for any role, and I'm looking forward to it.

[Reporter:]
When you were declared fit and started playing the warm-up games, Surya said you've come back as a better player with a stronger mindset. What was your mindset during rehab? Did the break help you reset before the big tournament?

[Tilak Verma:]
First of all, if I have to sit for a couple of days without a bat in my hands, I feel very strange. It feels like I'm in a different world.
Every night before sleeping, I visualize playing in big matches, even the World Cup final, and putting myself under pressure. It's a habit from childhood. I've been playing for so many years that these thoughts come naturally before I sleep.
So I don't worry about breaks. My mind stays in the same positive zone. I keep preparing mentally. I didn't feel like I was out of the game because of injury. I stayed in the zone, focused on winning matches, and reacted to the situations when I returned.

[Reporter:]
In tomorrow's match and the one in Ahmedabad, do you want to experiment to find the perfect combination before the Super 8?

[Tilak Verma:]
There is still time before the Super 8 and the final. We have to go match by match. First, we will focus on tomorrow's match.
The main thing is what we can do well in that game. So we'll think about that and approach the match accordingly. If everything goes well, the rest will take care of itself.

[Reporter:]
After the openers, it's often said that the batting positions from three to five will be flexible. How do you look at your batting position? Are you preparing for different roles?

[Tilak Verma:]
As I said, I'm ready to play in any position. But I believe the middle overs are very important and should be handled by a settled batsman.
I try to take the game deep, especially when we are chasing. We have a lot of power-hitters all the way down to number eight, so someone needs to anchor the innings in the middle overs. I take that responsibility on myself.
Every match is different—the wicket, the conditions, the bowlers. Even against the same team, every day is different. So I focus on the present and react to the situation instead of thinking too far ahead.

[Reporter:]
Going back to the Mumbai game, was the collapse more about reading the conditions or shot selection? How did it become 77 for 6?

[Tilak Verma:]
To be honest, at the start, when Abhishek got out, I went in and felt the ball was coming nicely onto the bat. I thought the wicket was fine, but actually it wasn't. I was just in that flow.
Unfortunately, it happens. People also felt it was playing well. But after a few wickets fell, we realized we had assessed the pitch a bit late. We had one or two soft dismissals as well.
But the way Surya played was a masterclass. That's the strength of this team. We haven't lost a bilateral series because someone always takes responsibility. That's a big sign. In this tournament, especially in the Super 8 or knockouts, such innings will be crucial.

[Reporter:]
Most of the players were champions in 2024, but for some, including you, this is the first World Cup. What's different about playing your first World Cup, especially in India?

[Tilak Verma:]
First of all, it's a dream. Playing a World Cup in home conditions is very special. Starting the first match at Wankhede was also special. Not every cricketer gets to experience that.
At the same time, there is pressure because everyone expects you to win at home. We saw the support from the crowd in the last match. So there are expectations and pressure, but also strong support.
There are advantages and disadvantages, but we've been handling pressure since childhood. We're enjoying it now, and we'll see how it goes.

[Reporter:]
India vs Pakistan is coming up. Pakistan's spinners are doing well in Colombo. What is your preparation and mindset for that match?

[Tilak Verma:]
We're taking it one match at a time. We'll use video analysis and technology to study their bowlers and the conditions. We've already started preparing.
We have all kinds of shots in our team, so depending on the wicket and the situation, we'll decide whether to attack or play accordingly. We'll pick the best team for the conditions and go from there.

[Reporter:]
There was talk earlier that only the top two positions were fixed, with flexibility after that. But now it seems like you and Surya are set at three and four. What has changed?

[Tilak Verma:]
World Cups come with high expectations and pressure. We've done well at numbers three and four. In those positions, we can find gaps and rotate the strike.
Our openers are aggressive, and we have powerful hitters down the order. So the middle overs become very important. I believe the team that performs well between overs 6 and 16 usually wins the match.
That's why Surya and I are taking responsibility in those positions—to manage the pressure and set things up for the finishers. That's the plan we've discussed.

[Reporter:]
After the difficult batting performance against the USA, what did the head coach say in the dressing room?

[Tilak Verma:]
To be honest, Gautam sir didn't say much. He said it happens once in a while. In pressure situations, we gave away a couple of wickets. He told us we should read the conditions earlier.
We usually play with an aggressive approach, but when wickets fall, sometimes we need to hold back for a couple of overs before accelerating again, especially considering our batting depth.
He said he would back whatever we decided as players, and that we should continue playing with the same intensity. That was the main message.

education.headline: The role of data analytics in modern advertising educationThis transformation also exercises a significant impact on the realm of 'advertising education.'

Forest fires surge tenfold from 2004 to 2017: Causes, impact and preventionAmidst a relentless surge, intense forest fires are now multiplying tenfold, casting a menacing shadow over our flora and fauna. Year by year, their fiery grip tightens, threatening ecosystems far and wide, now extending their reach to impact human lives.

He also claimed that the ruling party is "not fighting the Lok Sabha elections as a team".
